questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following accurately describes Sampson's theory for endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Sampson's theory describes the implantation of endometrial tissue due to retrograde 
menstruation. The various theories for the etiology of endometriosis include: Given below is an illustration showing retrograde menstrual flow that is leading to the 
development of patches of endometriosis. 645 
Sold by @itachibot Theory 
Mechanism Reflux of menstrual endomet 
rium and subsequent implant

pond to hormone stimulation Theory of coelomic metaplasi

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?

options.c: In utero exposure to DES increases risk
options.d: Most common site is the cervix

questions.explanation:
The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary is 
known as endometrioma. By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands and 
stroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (except 
spleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc. It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between the 
age groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are as 
follows: • Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative) • Nulliparity 646 
Sold by @itachibot • In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES) • Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy • Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman 
may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the most common symptom associated with endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea. Pain begins before the onset of menstruation and builds up continuously until the flow starts. 
Thereafter, the pain gradually declines. This pattern of pain is called triple dysmenorrhea.

questions.question:
Question 4: In a patient diagnosed with endometriosis, which of the following symptoms would you not 
expect?
questions.explanation: Patients diagnosed with endometriosis are not likely to present with vaginal discharge. Clinical features of endometriosis include: • About 30% of the patients are asymptomatic. • The classic symptom complex includes: • Dysmenorrhoea • Dyspareunia • Menorrhagia • Infertility (30-40%) • Dysmenorrhoea - most common symptom • Dyspareunia - occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved. • Deep-seated pelvic pain • Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting

questions.question:
Question 5: A 2…-year-old lady presented with complaints of severe pain on menstruation and heavy flow. 
She is subsequently diagnosed with endometriosis. The pain in this condition mainly 
correlates with
questions.explanation:
Pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with the depth of penetration. Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. 
The dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis precedes menses by 24 to 48 hours and is less 
responsive to NSAIDs and combined OCPs.

questions.question: Question 6: Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in the order of frequency of occurrence.
questions.explanation:
647 
Sold by @itachibot The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouch 
of Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube. Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On 
examination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. Which of the following 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament points 
towards a diagnosis of endometriosis. The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestone 
appearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'. The below image shows the cobblestone appearance of the uterosacral ligament. Note: Endometrioma or chocolate cyst is endometriosis of the ovary. It presents as an adnexal 
mass.

questions.question:
Question 8: 640 
Sold by @itachibot A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation and 
postmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix and 
a fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to 
confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a 
retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the 
diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological 
confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition. Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis: • Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging • To take biopsy 648 
Sold by @itachibot • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation Other investigations for endometriosis include: • Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis. • Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of 
women with endometriosis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea 
and dyspareunia. The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the 
pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis. On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish 
dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the 
peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a 
variable degree of fibrosis. Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are: • Red flame-shaped areas • Red polypoid areas • Yellow-brown patches • White peritoneal plaques or scarring • Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome • Subovarian adhesions. The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas. Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains 
prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of 
the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium 
lining. The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of 
Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of 
Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved. 649 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: In endometriotic lesion, histology represents its: 641 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity. Endometriosis is defined by the presence of “ectopic” endometrial tissue at a site outside of the 
uterus. Endometriosis is a proliferative hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. It 
is extremely rare before menarche and disappears after menopause. The endometriotic implants show certain differences when compared to normal endometrium. 
There is increased production of estrogen by endometriotic stromal cells due to high levels of the 
enzyme aromatase. This is absent in normal endometrial stroma. Management of endometriosis: 650 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following operative procedures are least likely to be followed by scar 
endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Among the given operative procedures, hysterectomy is least likely to be followed by scar 
endometriosis. Operations most likely to be followed by scar endometriosis are: • Hysterotomy • Classical Cesarean section • Myomectomy • Ventrofixation (fixing uterus to the abdominal wall) • Episiotomy

questions.question:
Question 12: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing, 
painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which was 
excised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements is 
false about this condition?

options.a: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
options.b: It is lined by columnar epithelium
options.c: It is usually a bilateral condition
options.d: It is a malignant cystic lesion

questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a 
benign cystic lesion. Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually 
affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present 
which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood 
pigments such as haemosiderin. They are polyhedral in shape and resemble lutein cells. Given below is a gross image of the chocolate cyst of the ovary. Given below is a histopathological section of an endometriotic lesion showing the 
pseudoxanthoma cells. 651 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal pain. Her lab reports revealed elevated 
CA-125 levels. Which of the following conditions is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
CA-125 levels are not expected to be elevated in malignant pancreatic tumours. CA-125 is a glycoprotein and cell surface antigen. Its levels are raised in the following conditions: • Abdominal or pelvic tuberculosis • Pelvic inflammatory disease • Endometriosis • Malignant epithelial ovarian tumour • Chronic liver disease • 2% of normal women, especially during menstruation. Endometrioma refers to ovarian endometriosis. CA-125 levels are raised to more than 35 U/mL in 
80% of cases of endometriosis. The level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 30-year-old woman with dyspareunia is diagnosed to have endometriosis. Which of the 
following drugs is not useful for her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent. For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated 
menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual 
flow. For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They are 
known to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. The 
drug of choice is GnRH agonists. 652 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with endometriosis requires treatment with GnRH analogues. She is scared of 
injections so you plan to prescribe a nasal preparation for her. Which of the following GnRH 
agonists could you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
The GnRH agonist available as a nasal preparation for the treatment of endometriosis is nafarelin. GnRH analogues are used in the management of endometriosis and are given by continuous 
administration. This suppresses the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins and leads to atrophy of 
the endometrial tissue in 90% of cases. Leuprolide and triptorelin are GnRH agonists which are given IM. Goserelin is available as a 
depot preparation.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
questions.explanation:
Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the 
endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, 
repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in 
multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and 
dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus 
corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is 
known as Halban's sign. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined 
with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. 
Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing 
IUCD can be tried in younger patients. 653 
Sold by @itachibot The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis. The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; 
the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with menorrhagia and backache is diagnosed with adenomyosis. Which of the 
following is not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Adenomyosis is not associated with sub involution of the uterus. Uterine subinvolution is impaired or retarded involution of the uterus. It is associated with 
uterine fibroid, cesarean section and conditions causing overdistension of the uterus like twin 
pregnancies or polyhydramnios. Adenomyosis often coexists with the following conditions: • Uterine fibromyomas 654 
Sold by @itachibot • Pelvic endometriosis (15%) • Endometrial carcinoma

questions.question:
Question 18: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. 
On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. 
Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind 
appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is 
hysterectomy. Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the 
endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical 
assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On 
bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of 
subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for 
diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination. Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is 
the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in 
younger women. The image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. 
Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity. 655 
Sold by @itachibot 656 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Ovary
